title: Sexist chip shop rejects trans man because ‘women work harder’
text:
Jorge Gorman was desperate to find a new job to be closer to his girlfriend (Picture: Kennedy News and Media/Google Maps)

A chippy manager has been accused of gender discrimination after turning down a job seeker because ‘women are better and work harder’.

Jobless Jorge Gorman, 33, who was born female, said the response he got from The Anchor Fish and Chips in Nottingham was ‘absolutely ridiculous’.

He has more than 15 years experience in the food and drinks sector but was told the business is only looking for female staff to take customers’ orders over the phone.

The acting manager stood by his comments, denied discrimination and said it was only his opinion that women were better at this particular job than men.

But the chippy’s owner has since said he was wrong to make his remarks, and insisted people of all genders could apply.

He says this was all he got in response from the chippy (Picture: Kennedy News and Media)

Jorge, from Wellingborough, Northamptonshire has been looking for jobs for three months to move closer to his partner, Emma, 26, who lives an hour and a half away in Nottingham.

He said: ‘It’s shocking that it happened – they put it in writing too.

‘I’ve been discriminated against because of my gender. They’ve just said no. It’s sexism pure and simple.

‘It’s absolutely ridiculous to say women are more hardworking or polite.’

Jorge said they stuck by their comments and mentioned it in a now deleted post on their Facebook page.

He added: ‘They said “in my opinion women are better on phone by taking takeaway orders of customers. They’re patient, they are hard working.”‘

Jorge, who was born female before transitioning, says it is ‘absolutely ridiculous’ to say women are better at the role (Picture: Kennedy News and Media)

Jorge sent his CV and covering letter saw the advert on Facebook, which he used to send across his covering letter and CV.

After being refused by the chip shop, incensed supporters urged him to report the business for gender discrimination.

He added: ‘My confidence hasn’t been knocked because I’ve had some nice comments, but I’ve been looking for work now for the last few months.

‘I’d clean toilets if I had to – I’m one of those people.’

‘People are telling me to report them and I think I probably should, for other people too.

‘They need to know what they’ve done it wrong. They can’t know it’s wrong because you wouldn’t put it in writing, surely?’

Advertisement

A man who identified himself as the acting manager of Anchor Fish and Chips admitted to sending the message to Jorge.

He said: ‘Nothing was about discrimination – it was just a misunderstanding.

‘Basically, we have had a few guys working here answering the phone but they weren’t doing the job properly.

‘We have a girl who has been working with us for more than a year. So I thought it was right to have a female answer the phone talking to people.

‘I did not know it was illegal. I did not mean to discriminate against people.

The owner of the chip shop has distanced himself from the manager’s comments (Picture: Google Maps)

‘I couldn’t post the advert just for a female. In my opinion, females do this job better than male staff. I just said ‘in my opinion. I didn’t say it was a fact.’

After Jorge shared his complaint online, he says the chippy doubled down in a post on their Facebook account, which has now been deleted.

They said: ‘In my opinion, women are better for this job.

‘We do have men and women drive[r]s, which is absolutely fine. I believe women are better and [more] patient for taking takeaway orders.

‘If you run a business you need to have [the] right people in [the] right shifts and positions. I hope it’s clear enough why.’

The owner has since distanced himself from the manager’s comments said he would be happy to hire a man or woman for the job.

Advertisement

He added: ‘I’ll change my password [to our social media page]. He is not supposed to post stuff like that.

‘I’ll definitely do something about this. That’s not the case. It’s not my opinion.’

description: Jorge Gorman was rejected by the manager of The Anchor Fish and Chips in Nottingham who said women are 'better' at taking customer's orders.
